chargeHist.descr: Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal)

result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th) and OWI (5th or 6th). The defendant was found guilty of Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th) and the other charge, OWI (5th or 6th) was dismissed by the court.

  • Charles Walter Kysilka was found guilty of Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Letter from DEF:  Regarding Sentence Credit
Associated with Charge #2

11:42 AM Defendant Charles Walter Kysilka in court with attorney Christian J Ness apears by video.  Defendant Charles Walter Kysilka in custody.  Jennifer Gross appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court calls case and recites appearances.    Plea Questionnaire eletronically submitted to Court.  Attny Ness indicates plea questionnaire review with DEF via telephone.  DEF agrees, Court proceeds with plea/sentencing.  State recites agreement, all parties agree.  DEF enters NC plea to Count 2.   DEF advised of rights and penalties; DEF waives rights; parties stipulate to facts.    Court accepts plea of Count 2 and finds DEF guilty.   Count 1  is merged and dismissed by operation of law and 3 is dismissed and read in.   State makes statement prior to sentencing.  Attny Ness makes statement prior to sentencing.   DEF makes statement to court.    Court follows agreement.

COURT:  withheld sentence.    3 years probation.  1 year county jail.  Good time, huber privileges.   118 days days credit.    Fine/Costs  $1,872.00    DEF must provide DNA sample and pay applicable $250 surcharge.   24 months Revoked driver license,   DOT to credit any administrative suspension and add any period of incarceration to revocation sentence.  IID requirements 24 months,   On any vehicle owned or operated.  OWI assessment within 72 hours and AODA assessment  within 45 days and follow-through with recommendations.    Attend Victim Impact Panel, obtain a driver.    Complete any counseling and programming deemed appropriate by agent, and follow through. assessment and maintain compliance with driver safety plan.
Plea/sentencing hearing on January 28, 2022 at 11:30 am.

11:47 AM Defendant Charles Walter Kysilka in court with attorney Christian J Ness appears by video.  Defendant Charles Walter Kysilka in custody appears by video.  Jennifer Gross appeared for the State of Wisconsin.    Court calls case and recites appearances.  
Attny  Ness acknowledges information, waives reading.  DEF enters NG plea to Count 1 and 2.  Court finds probable cause and binds DEF over for trial.  Attny Ness request to be set for plea/sentencing date.  Court set.  Plea/sentencing hearing scheduled for January 28, 2022 at 11:30 am.
Arraignment on December 15, 2021 at 11:00 am.

11:54 AM Defendant Charles Walter Kysilka in court with attorney Christian J Ness appears by video.  Defendant Charles Walter Kysilka in custody appears by video.  Jennifer Gross appeared for the State of Wisconsin.   Court calls case and recites appearances.  Attny Ness indicates to proceed with preliminary hearing.   State calls witness, City of Hayward, Assistant Chief  Wohling, sworn in by Court.   State begins examinations.  11:58 AM  Witness identified the DEF, court indicates the record will reflect.  State continues examination. 11:58 AM  Witness reviews report.  State continues examination.   11:59 AM State tenders witness.   11:59 AM  Cross-Examination by Attorney Ness.   Attny Ness no further questions.  12:00 PM  Witness excused.   No further witness by either party.   State request for bind over.  Attny Ness no argument to probable cause.  Court finds probable cause and binds defendant over for trial.  
  Arraignment scheduled for December 15, 2021 at 11:00 am.

11:04AM Defendant Charles Walter Kysilka in court, appearing by video from in custody in Sawyer County Jail, with attorney Christian J Ness.  Jennifer Gross appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court calls case (15CM415, 15CT75) and recites appearances.  Atty Ness indicates offer received, requests PLEAS be set.  Court informs parties INIT has not been completed.  Parties agree to complete INIT at this time.    DEF advised of rights and penalties; DEF waives rights; parties stipulate to facts.  Court enters NG plea for misdemeanor on behalf of DEF.  All parties have discussion on setting prelim.  Atty Ness indicates waiver of time limits, DEF agrees.  Court sets prelim for 11/2/21 at 8:45AM  Hearing scheduled for November 2, 2021 at 08:45 am.

SPECIAL BOND Conditions with Random Testing  by blood, breath, or urine
1. Defendant shall not consume any intoxicating beverages.
2. Defendant shall not enter the premises of any business that sells or serves alcoholic beverages by the drink.
EXCEPT that defendant may be on the premises of: 
for the purpose of employment, but only for the purpose of employment and only during his/her hours of employment.
3. Defendant shall be subject to RANDOM TESTING if his/her blood, breath or urine, and shall report to the Sawyer County Human Services Department at 10610 Main Street, Hayward, WI (ph. 715-638-3317) within 48 hours upon release from custody (not counting weekends and holidays) to schedule an intake session with the Sawyer County Traffic Offender Program (STOP) and to establish the procedures for the random testing.
